text: one of the worst countries in the world
to be a woman they might have come a
long way since a repressive Taliban
regime but freedom is too limited
equality a distant dream and everyday
here they face the threat of violence
rape harassment in the market on the
streets women regularly have lewd
comments pass to them and are often
inappropriately touched but now there
are disturbing allegations that sexual
harassment is rampant at the highest
levels of government men in positions of
power asking for sexual favors in return
for jobs or harrassing their
subordinates
we're in Kabul to probe these claims
it's hard to find women willing to speak
out in a conservative male-dominated
society but our investigation has
finally led us to a former government
employee we're hiding her identity
because she fears a backlash she told me
her boss a senior minister repeatedly
suggested that she should have sex with
him and then one day tried to physically
assault her when I went to see him he
told me the reason I selected you was
because I want you to be my friend he
was asking for sex directly from me I
told him I'm qualified I never thought
he would say such things to me I stood
up to leave he grabbed my hand and took
me to a room at the back of his office
he pushed me towards the room and told
me it'll take only a few minutes don't
worry come with me I pushed him by his
chest and said enough don't make me
scream and did you file a complaint
after this incident no I resigned from
my job I don't trust the government you
can't find a safe place to go and
complain if you speak out everyone will
blame the woman she also told us two
other women had come forward to tell her
the same Minister had raped them claims
the BBC has been unable to independently
verify it's not just one individual
ministry or Department several women
we've spoken to have told us that sexual
harassment is widespread in the
government most of them are too afraid
to speak out but now we're going to meet
another woman who's willing to share her
story with us in fact this is the first
time she's telling anyone about it she
had all but secured a government job
when she was asked to meet a close aide
of President Ashraf Ghani tomorrow job
Namita then he asked me to come to his
private office he said come sit I'll
approve your documents he was moving
closer to me and then said let's drink
and have sex it was really shocking I
got scared and left last year she
contested parliamentary polls and says
Election Commission officials also
harassed her during the election even
officers of the lowest ranks knew that
you had to go through them for any work
to be done they would ask me to come and
sit in their private offices and drink
with them if you go to complain to a
judge the police a prosecutor any of
those they'll ask you for sex so if
they're doing that who can you go to
it's like it's become a part of the
culture now that every man around you
wants to have sex with you in Kabul such
stories have either gone untold or were
discussed in hushed whispers until they
were thrust into the spotlight in me by
this man general ahmad sigh a former
adviser to the president now his
political rival who spoke about it in a
TV interview the president's office
declined the BBC's request for an
interview they told us they had no
comment beyond this statement
all of general amis ice allegations are
baseless and he's lying because of his
personal interests the president's legal
team will get in touch with the attorney
general's office and request him to ask
mr. Amazigh to provide evidence of his
claims the government's reaction to the
allegations has drawn criticism the
response that the government gave is
defensive I think the culture of
impunity is one of the reasons the
people who commit this don't get trial
so therefore the man who or the
perpetrators feel protected the Attorney
General has launched a probe into the
matter I'm here with a from the BBC I
met his spokesman in Cabo how do you
expect the office of a man who's been
appointed by the President to
investigate allegations that could
potentially involve people from the
president's own government how do you
expect people to believe that that's
going to be an impartial investigation a
draw to a core ha the Constitution has
given the right to the Attorney General
to be independent we've also asked
activists Muslim clerics and human
rights organizations to be a part of the
investigation to assure people that we
are impartial this is a country where
democracy has come at the cost of tens
of thousands of lives the war against
radical Islamist groups here promised
dignity for Afghanistan's women foreign
nations continue to help keep the
elected government in power
there are more women in Parliament and
in government now but if they are not
considered safe places to work progress
that was hard-fought could come to a
halt yoga thalam a BBC News Kabul
